conclusion: The instantaneous rate at which the displacement difference Δs = sA – sB changes is the relative velocity vr = vA – vB.
During 0 ≤ t ≤ t1 the curve for A is everywhere above the curve for B.
vA > vB at every instant in the interval 0 ≤ t ≤ t1, hence vr > 0 for all t in (0, t1).
Because vr is positive and continuous, its time-integral – the displacement difference Δs – increases continuously with time.
The separation in displacement between the two objects grows monotonically from t = 0 to t = t1; it never decreases or stays constant at any instant inside that interval.
Final answer: Yes, the displacement difference between objects A and B is necessarily continuously increasing throughout 0 ≤ t ≤ t1.
